title: 1.1: First Emission
summary: Create your first particle system with basic blocks
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to create a simple particle system using the Node Particle Editor. We'll start with the fundamental blocks: SystemBlock, UpdatePositionBlock, and CreateParticleBlock.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>BoxShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a box volume and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block to handle particle movement and connect between BoxShape and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Position</filter-value> block to get the current position and connect to UpdatePosition block
Add a <filter-value>ScaledDirection</filter-value> block to get the scaled direction
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to combine position and direction and connect Position and ScaledDirection blocks to the left and right inputs respectively
Connect the result from the math block to UpdatePosition's position input

blocks.name: SystemBlock
blocks.description: The root block of any particle system. It manages the overall system properties and connects to all particle-related blocks.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the particle system

blocks.name: UpdatePositionBlock
blocks.description: Updates the position of particles each frame. This block is essential for any particle movement.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

blocks.name: CreateParticleBlock
blocks.description: Creates new particles. This block is responsible for particle emission.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

blocks.name: BoxShapeBlock
blocks.description: Defines a box-shaped emitter. Particles will be created within this box volume.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock
blocks.description: Retrieves contextual particle data such as position, velocity, or age. In this lesson, we use it to get the current position and scaled direction.

properties.name: contextualValue
properties.description: The type of contextual data to retrieve

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock
blocks.description: Performs mathematical operations on particle data. We use it to add position and direction vectors.

properties.name: operation
properties.description: The mathematical operation to perform (Add, Subtract, Multiply, Divide, etc.)

blocks.name: ParticleTextureSourceBlock
blocks.description: Provides a texture for particles. This determines how particles look when rendered.

properties.name: url
properties.description: The URL of the texture image to use

codeCopy: The code creates a NodeParticleSystemSet and builds a graph of connected blocks. Each block has a specific function, and they're connected using the connectTo() method.
objectives: Understand the basic structure of a particle system
Learn how to connect blocks using connectTo() method
Create particles using CreateParticleBlock and BoxShapeBlock
Use ParticleInputBlock to retrieve contextual particle data
Apply mathematical operations to combine position and direction
Understand the particle flow: Create → Shape → Update → System

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to connect blocks in the correct order
commonMistakes.explanation: Blocks must be connected in a logical flow. The CreateParticleBlock must connect to a shape, then to update blocks, and finally to the SystemBlock.
commonMistakes.solution: Follow the chain: CreateParticleBlock → ShapeBlock → UpdateBlocks → SystemBlock. Each block should connect its output to the next block's input.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using wrong contextual value in ParticleInputBlock
commonMistakes.explanation: ParticleInputBlock can retrieve different types of data (Position, Direction, Age, etc.). Using the wrong type will give incorrect results.
commonMistakes.solution: Make sure to set contextualValue correctly: NodeParticleContextualSources.Position for position, NodeParticleContextualSources.ScaledDirection for direction.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not connecting the final result to SystemBlock
commonMistakes.explanation: The SystemBlock is the root of the particle system. If update blocks aren't connected to it, particles won't be updated.
commonMistakes.solution: Always connect the last update block (UpdatePositionBlock) to SystemBlock using systemBlock.updateBlocks.push(updateBlock).

homework: Try changing the BoxShapeBlock to a different shape
Modify the math operation to see how it affects particle movement
